posts.author: elvisbird
posts.title:
Ashley Biden's Charity Failed To Disclose $500,000 in Donations to IRS, Complaint Alleges
Someone forget to pardon Ashley

link_metadata.description: Ashley Biden's charity has a $500,000 discrepancy in its books, a watchdog alleged in a complaint filed with the IRS on Monday. During the height of her father’s presidency in 2023, Ashley Biden launched a walk-in trauma recovery center in Philadelphia equipped with infrared saunas to help women overcome mental health challenges. Known as the Women’s Wellness Spa(ce), the former first daughter’s charity supposedly got off the ground with at least $500,000 in seed funding in 2023. Meghan Markle and Prince Harry’s Archewell Foundation and the Silicon Valley Community Foundation each reported in their tax forms granting $250,000 to Ashley Biden’s charitable venture in 2023, figures that should have been reflected in the Women’s Wellness Spa(ce)’s Form 990 tax filing.
link_metadata.title: Ashley Biden's Charity Failed To Disclose $500,000 in Donations to IRS, Complaint Alleges

posts.raw_content:
Yeesh.... Grok pulled no punches.

Based on the above, here’s a ranking of effectiveness, with Johnson placed among his predecessors. Rankings reflect achievements relative to context, not absolute power or popularity.
Nancy Pelosi (2007–2011, 2019–2023): Unmatched legislative record (ACA, infrastructure), strong party control, and navigated polarization. Her ability to pass major bills with slim majorities sets the gold standard.

Tip O’Neill (1977–1987): Masterfully balanced Carter’s and Reagan’s agendas, maintained Democratic dominance, and shaped the Speakership’s modern role.

Newt Gingrich (1995–1999): Transformed the House with the “Contract with America,” but effectiveness waned due to scandals and Clinton’s counter-strategy.

Dennis Hastert (1999–2007): Long tenure, major Bush-era laws, and GOP unity, but later scandals and 2006 losses dim his legacy.

Carl Albert (1971–1977): Handled Watergate and Vietnam-era reforms effectively but was less dominant in a committee-driven era.

John Boehner (2011–2015): Managed crises but was hamstrung by Tea Party revolts, limiting GOP wins.

Paul Ryan (2015–2019): Delivered tax cuts but failed on broader GOP goals (e.g., Obamacare repeal), retiring amid losses.

Tom Foley (1989–1995): Respectable but lost to GOP wave, reflecting failure to adapt to shifting politics.

Jim Wright (1987–1989): Short tenure marred by ethics issues, though he pushed some legislative wins.

Mike Johnson (2023–Present): Stabilized the House post-McCarthy but has minimal legislative output, relies on Democrats and Trump, and struggles with party unity. His inexperience and narrow majority constrain him.

Kevin McCarthy (2023): Least effective; ousted quickly, unable to control GOP or pass significant legislation.

Critical Analysis
Why Johnson Ranks Low: Johnson’s tenure is marked by survival rather than dominance. His legislative record is thin, with no signature laws comparable to Pelosi’s ACA or Gingrich’s welfare reform. His dependence on Democratic votes (e.g., funding bills, surviving ouster) and Trump’s endorsements undermines his autonomy, unlike O’Neill or Hastert, who wielded independent authority. The Center for Effective Lawmaking rated him the 27th most effective Republican in Congress pre-Speakership, reflecting his limited legislative heft. The 118th Congress’s low productivity and ongoing GOP infighting further weaken his record.

Contextual Defense: Johnson inherited a dysfunctional House, a narrower majority than any predecessor (219–215 vs. Pelosi’s 222–213 or Gingrich’s 230–204), and a polarized era where single-member motions to vacate empowered rebels. His ability to secure the gavel twice and pass a rules package under these constraints is notable, surpassing McCarthy’s failure. The 119th Congress’s unified GOP control offers potential for future wins, but these are speculative as of April 2025.

Counter-Narrative: Establishment sources (e.g., NPR, Reuters) often frame Johnson as a weak Speaker due to his reliance on external forces, but this overlooks the structural challenges of modern GOP dynamics. His “member-driven” approach and outreach to the Freedom Caucus (e.g., promising inclusion in tax and immigration bills) could yield long-term unity, unlike McCarthy’s top-down failures. However, his low public approval (40% unsure in 2023) and lack of a transformative agenda akin to Gingrich’s limit his current impact.

Conclusion
Mike Johnson ranks 10th among the last 10 Speakers, ahead only of Kevin McCarthy. His stabilization of the House post-2023 chaos, survival of ouster attempts, and navigation of a slim majority are modest achievements, but his sparse legislative record, reliance on Democrats and Trump, and struggles with GOP unity pale against predecessors like Pelosi, Gingrich, or O’Neill. While his tenure is ongoing and the 119th Congress could elevate his standing (e.g., via Trump’s tax cuts or border security laws), current evidence places him near the bottom. His inexperience and external pressures contrast sharply with the institutional mastery of top-ranked Speakers.
posts.author: pwnahontas
posts.title: Even Grok thinks Mike Johnson sucks.  "Ranking Mike Johnson Among the Last 10 Speakers"
posts.content:
Yeesh.... Grok pulled no punches.

Based on the above, here’s a ranking of effectiveness, with Johnson placed among his predecessors. Rankings reflect achievements relative to context, not absolute power or popularity. Nancy Pelosi (2007–2011, 2019–2023): Unmatched legislative record (ACA, infrastructure), strong party control, and navigated polarization. Her ability to pass major bills with slim majorities sets the gold standard.

Tip O’Neill (1977–1987): Masterfully balanced Carter’s and Reagan’s agendas, maintained Democratic dominance, and shaped the Speakership’s modern role.

Newt Gingrich (1995–1999): Transformed the House with the “Contract with America,” but effectiveness waned due to scandals and Clinton’s counter-strategy.

Dennis Hastert (1999–2007): Long tenure, major Bush-era laws, and GOP unity, but later scandals and 2006 losses dim his legacy.

Carl Albert (1971–1977): Handled Watergate and Vietnam-era reforms effectively but was less dominant in a committee-driven era.

John Boehner (2011–2015): Managed crises but was hamstrung by Tea Party revolts, limiting GOP wins.

Paul Ryan (2015–2019): Delivered tax cuts but failed on broader GOP goals (e.g., Obamacare repeal), retiring amid losses.

Tom Foley (1989–1995): Respectable but lost to GOP wave, reflecting failure to adapt to shifting politics.

Jim Wright (1987–1989): Short tenure marred by ethics issues, though he pushed some legislative wins.

Mike Johnson (2023–Present): Stabilized the House post-McCarthy but has minimal legislative output, relies on Democrats and Trump, and struggles with party unity. His inexperience and narrow majority constrain him.

Kevin McCarthy (2023): Least effective; ousted quickly, unable to control GOP or pass significant legislation.

Critical Analysis Why Johnson Ranks Low: Johnson’s tenure is marked by survival rather than dominance. His legislative record is thin, with no signature laws comparable to Pelosi’s ACA or Gingrich’s welfare reform. His dependence on Democratic votes (e.g., funding bills, surviving ouster) and Trump’s endorsements undermines his autonomy, unlike O’Neill or Hastert, who wielded independent authority. The Center for Effective Lawmaking rated him the 27th most effective Republican in Congress pre-Speakership, reflecting his limited legislative heft. The 118th Congress’s low productivity and ongoing GOP infighting further weaken his record.

Contextual Defense: Johnson inherited a dysfunctional House, a narrower majority than any predecessor (219–215 vs. Pelosi’s 222–213 or Gingrich’s 230–204), and a polarized era where single-member motions to vacate empowered rebels. His ability to secure the gavel twice and pass a rules package under these constraints is notable, surpassing McCarthy’s failure. The 119th Congress’s unified GOP control offers potential for future wins, but these are speculative as of April 2025.

Counter-Narrative: Establishment sources (e.g., NPR, Reuters) often frame Johnson as a weak Speaker due to his reliance on external forces, but this overlooks the structural challenges of modern GOP dynamics. His “member-driven” approach and outreach to the Freedom Caucus (e.g., promising inclusion in tax and immigration bills) could yield long-term unity, unlike McCarthy’s top-down failures. However, his low public approval (40% unsure in 2023) and lack of a transformative agenda akin to Gingrich’s limit his current impact.

Conclusion Mike Johnson ranks 10th among the last 10 Speakers, ahead only of Kevin McCarthy. His stabilization of the House post-2023 chaos, survival of ouster attempts, and navigation of a slim majority are modest achievements, but his sparse legislative record, reliance on Democrats and Trump, and struggles with GOP unity pale against predecessors like Pelosi, Gingrich, or O’Neill. While his tenure is ongoing and the 119th Congress could elevate his standing (e.g., via Trump’s tax cuts or border security laws), current evidence places him near the bottom. His inexperience and external pressures contrast sharply with the institutional mastery of top-ranked Speakers.
